turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Operation Barras.
turn.2: The released soldiers were flown for debriefing to RFA "Sir Percivale", of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary, off the coast.
turn.3: What did they do after being released?
turn.4: After the release of the soldiers, the West Side Boys' spokesman, the self-styled "Colonel Cambodia", used the satellite telephone to contact the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) for a lengthy interview in which they outlined a series of demands, including a re-negotiation of the Lomé Peace Accord and the release of prisoners held by the Sierra Leone authorities.
turn.6: The BBC had prior warning from the Foreign Office that the interview would take place.
turn.7: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.8: " Colonel Cambodia" quickly depleted the batteries in the telephone, but his call to the BBC enabled specialists from the Royal Corps of Signals to determine the exact position of the telephone.
turn.9: What did they do after depleting the batteries?
turn.10: The West Side Boys were unstable, possibly due to use of cannabis and cocaine, and their behaviour during the crisis was erratic.
turn.12: After their release, the five soldiers described an incident in which Kallay, dissatisfied with their explanation, conducted a mock execution in which he threatened to shoot the soldiers unless they told him why they had entered the West Side Boys' territory.
